channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Netanyahu’s Coalition Appears Steady After Court Ruling
item.description: The order finding that the Israeli military must draft ultra-Orthodox Jews risked splitting the coalition government, but there were no immediate threats from far-right ministers to pull out.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Iran’s Presidential Candidates Agree on One Thing: Trump Is Coming
item.description: The former U.S. president’s election is treated as a foregone conclusion, with the six contenders clashing over who is best suited to handling him.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Russia Opens Secret Trial of Evan Gershkovich of The Wall Street Journal
item.description: Evan Gershkovich of The Wall Street Journal has endured 15 months in prison by reading letters and Russian classics, while the authorities have not publicly offered any evidence that he was a spy.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Milana Mazaeva and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich standing inside a glass cage for defendants before he went on trial on Wednesday in Yekaterinburg, Russia.

item.title: NATO, at Washington Summit, Will Offer Ukraine a ‘Bridge’ to Membership
item.description: Officials say Kyiv won’t get membership negotiations at the coming NATO summit, but the alliance will announce a structure to coordinate aid over the longer term.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Ukraine’s 45th Brigade operating a Swedish-donated self-propelled howitzer in Ukraine’s northeastern Kharkiv Region this month.

item.title: Julian Assange Pleads Guilty to Espionage, Securing His Freedom
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder, who entered the plea in a U.S. courtroom in Saipan in the Western Pacific, arrived home to Australia on Wednesday night.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, arriving at a U.S. courthouse in Saipan in the Northern Mariana Islands on Wednesday morning.

item.title: Black-Clad Ultras Are a Fixture at Euro 2024
item.description: Hard-core fan groups, embracing a strong nationalistic streak, have provoked pushback from soccer’s authorities at the European Championship.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Members of the Carpathian Brigade, a Hungarian ultras group, at a match between Hungary and Switzerland during Euro 2024 this month. The group often echoes the rhetoric of their country’s prime minister, Viktor Orban.

item.title: Rogue to Victim: What Australia Sees in Julian Assange
item.description: Broad support for his release seems to have grown more out of resentment of his treatment by the U.S. justice system than concerns about press protections.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Julian Assange arriving at court in Saipan, the Northern Mariana Islands, on Wednesday to enter a guilty plea.

item.title: Mark Rutte Moves From Leading Netherlands to Heading NATO
item.description: Mr. Rutte, who served as the Dutch prime minister for nearly 14 years, has been a harsh critic of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, and a strong supporter of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Mark Rutte, the outgoing Dutch prime minister, will take over the post of secretary general of NATO from Jens Stoltenberg on Oct. 1.

item.title: Kenyan President Rejects Bill That Led to Deadly Protests
item.description: A day after at least 23 people were killed in demonstrations against a tax increase, President William Ruto withdrew the law that he said was necessary to avoid defaulting on the country’s debt.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The wreckage of a car burned on Tuesday in downtown Nairobi, Kenya, during protests over proposed tax increases.

item.title: Nigel Farage, a Trump Ally and Brexiteer, Shakes Up U.K. Politics, Again
item.description: With his populist, anti-immigration campaign, Nigel Farage is once more shaking up Britain’s politics. Can he finally win a seat in the national Parliament?
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The establishment are terrified, the Conservatives are terrified,” Nigel Farage told his supporters at an event in Clacton-on-Sea last week.

item.title: China’s Anguished Debate: Do Its Children Have a Crime Problem?
item.description: China has been considered relatively progressive on juvenile justice. But several high-profile killings have prompted calls for the law to come down more harshly on minors.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph of Gong Xinyue in her bedroom, in her village in northwestern China.

item.title: Deaths at Hajj and Big Events Highlight Failures to Adjust to Heat
item.description: The deaths of at least 1,300 pilgrims during the hajj point to the growing threat that climate change poses to beloved gatherings.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims used umbrellas to shade themselves from the sun during the hajj in Saudi Arabia this month.

item.title: How a French Far-Right Leader, Jordan Bardella, Helped Rebrand the National Rally
item.description: Many long considered Marine Le Pen’s party too extreme to be anywhere close to power. Now, the party could win a parliamentary election — and fill the prime minister’s seat.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jordan Bardella, the National Party’s president, is jockeying to become France’s next prime minister — something that 10 years ago would have been unthinkable.

item.title: Kenyan-Led Forces Arrive in Haiti After Months of Gang Violence
item.description: The arrival of 400 Kenyan officers came on a day of deadly violence in Kenya. The international force was sent to try to restore order in the gang-plagued Caribbean nation.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A photo released by the Kenyan presidential office shows deploying police officers praying with President William Ruto on Monday in Nairobi.

item.title: If You Give a Frog a Sauna, It Might Fight Off a Deadly Fungus
item.description: A fatal fungal disease has devastated the world’s amphibians. But the fungus has a vulnerability: It cannot tolerate heat.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: A Feline Scientist Explains Why Your Cat Might Actually Like You
item.description: Cats are more social than they are often given credit for. Can you help yours access its inner dog?
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Anti-tax protests tore through Kenya’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Tear gas exploded as protesters tried to help injured people outside Kenya’s Parliament.

item.title: Kenyan President Vows to Crack Down on ‘Treasonous’ Protesters
item.description: At least five people were killed in clashes with the police that erupted after lawmakers approved tax increases that critics said would drive up the cost of living for millions.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A tear-gas canister exploded on a street in Nairobi, Kenya, during protests over a bill to raise taxes.

item.title: Protests in Kenya Over Tax Bill: What to Know
item.description: Kenyan police faced off with protesters in the capital, Nairobi. Civic groups said that at least five people died.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Kenyans protesting against the finance bill Tuesday in Nairobi.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Major Protests in Nairobi
item.description: Also, Julian Assange’s plea deal with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A tear gas canister exploded as protesters tried to help injured people outside Kenya’s Parliament.

item.title: A Court Ruled an Exhibit Discriminated Against Men. Now It’s in the Women’s Restroom.
item.description: The Museum of Old and New Art in Tasmania hung several paintings in a women’s restroom after a court ruled that its installation could not be exclusive to women.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.category: Museum of Old and New Art
item.media:credit: Museum of Old and New Art
item.media:description: A Picasso painting hangs inside the women’s restroom at the Museum of Old and New Art in Tasmania, Australia.

item.title: Kenya Protests Are a Blow to Biden’s Embrace of President Ruto
item.description: Just a day earlier, President Biden had formally named Kenya a major non-NATO ally.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with President William Ruto of Kenya at the White House last month.

item.title: Who Is Julian Assange? What to Know About the WikiLeaks Founder and His Plea Deal
item.description: The deal ends a period of confinement that lasted about a dozen years, first in the self-exile of the Ecuadorean embassy in London, then in prison.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julian Assange in London in 2011. He pleaded guilty early Wednesday to a single count of illegally obtaining and disseminating national security information.

item.title: Kenya Police Force Has a Bloody Past With Protesters
item.description: The combination of a bloody clash with protesters in Nairobi and the arrival of Kenyan officers in gang-ravaged Haiti draws new scrutiny to the Kenyan police.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Evelyn Hockstein for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police fire tear gas during mass rallies to protest against the disputed re-election of President Mwai Kibaki in Nairobi, Kenya, in 2008.

item.title: Michael Phelps and Allison Schmitt Testify on Antidoping Measures Ahead of Olympics
item.description: Lawmakers expressed openness to withholding funding from the agency after reports that Chinese swimmers were allowed to compete in the 2021 Games after testing positive for a banned drug.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas and Michael S. Schmidt
item.category: House Committee on Energy and Commerce
item.media:description: The Olympic gold medalist Michael Phelps, who testified before Congress about a different doping scandal in 2017, said on Tuesday that he was “incredulous” to be back addressing the same issue seven years later.

item.title: The Southern Border, Terrorism Fears and the Arrests of 8 Tajik Men
item.description: The men were arrested after the F.B.I. quietly began an investigation that stretched across the country and involved scores of bureau personnel.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Eric Schmitt and Hamed Aleaziz
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Texas-Mexico border in 2023. Eight men from Tajikistan, with possible ties to the Islamic State, crossed into the United States in the past year.

item.title: Julian Assange’s Plea Deal Could Chill Press Freedoms
item.description: The deal brings an ambiguous end to a legal saga that has jeopardized the ability of journalists to report on military, intelligence or diplomatic information that officials deem secret.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Julian Assange after his arrest outside the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in 2019. By taking a plea deal, Mr. Assange will not raise any constitutional challenge testing the legitimacy of applying the Espionage Act to his actions.

item.title: Obama’s Half Sister Is Among Those Tear-Gassed During Protests in Kenya
item.description: Auma Obama, a sociologist and community activist, was being interviewed live on CNN when clouds of tear gas lobbed by the police overwhelmed her.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Auma Obama, an older half sister of former President Barack Obama, speaking in Frankfurt in 2021.

item.title: See Kenya’s Protests in Nairobi
item.description: Across the country, outrage over proposed tax increases drives Kenyans to the streets.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in the streets on Tuesday in downtown Nairobi, Kenya, during a strike to protest tax hikes included in a finance bill.

item.title: Russia Committed Human Rights Violations in Crimea, European Court Finds
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights listed multiple violations. Its findings paint a grim picture of life under a decade of Russian occupation.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign reading, “Together with Russia. Referendum 16 March,” was put up outside Simferopol in Crimea in 2014.

item.title: Strike in Gaza Kills Sister of Hamas’s Political Leader Haniyeh
item.description: Hamas confirmed the death of a sister of Ismail Haniyeh and her family. The Israeli military said it was aware of the reports but could not “currently confirm” that it had struck the Haniyeh family home.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, the political leader of Hamas, in Tehran in March.

item.title: I.C.C. Issues Arrest Warrants for Russian Officials Shoigu and Gerasimov
item.description: Sergei K. Shoigu, a former defense minister, and Gen. Valery V. Gerasimov, the country’s highest-ranking military officer, were accused of directing attacks against civilians in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Gen. Valery Gerasimov, left, and Sergei Shoigu, then Russia’s defense minister, in a photo released by Russian state media in 2023.

item.title: What Is a Famine and Who Determines That One Exists?
item.description: A group of global experts said that Gaza is at high risk of famine, but stopped short of saying that one had begun. Here’s a closer look at how famine is defined.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Waiting to receive food at a school in Jabaliya in northern Gaza this month.

item.title: Fire Exposes Harsh Work Conditions Migrants Face in South Korea
item.description: Activists say the blaze that killed 23 laborers at a battery plant, most of them from China, shows that such workers need better protection.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Emergency personnel and investigators at the scene of Aricell’s factory in Hwaseong, South Korea, on Tuesday, the day after the lethal fire.

item.title: Emperor Naruhito to Visit London’s Kew Gardens, Which Has Links to Japan
item.description: Emperor Naruhito is touring the famous botanic gardens this week as part of a state visit to Britain with his wife, Empress Masako.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors to Kew Gardens in London on Monday. The Japanese Gateway is in the background.

item.title: How Venezuela’s Leader Could Stay in Power No Matter What Voters Want
item.description: Four former officials in the government of President Nicolás Maduro describe his options between now and an election that could remove him from power — or solidify his grip.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Nicolás Maduro during a get-out-the-vote event this month in the capital, Caracas.

item.title: Three Ideas to Beat the Heat, and the People Who Made Them Happen
item.description: As temperatures soar around the world, practical experiments are emerging to protect people.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hansa Ahir, left, who salvages recyclable waste for a living in Ahmedabad, India, bought an insurance policy to cover her income on days when heat makes it dangerous to work.

item.title: When Sick Pets Need Blood, Animal ‘Superheroes’ Come to the Rescue
item.description: Transfusions have become an important part of veterinary medicine, but cat and dog blood is not always easy to come by.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Michael Hanson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jolie, a blood donor, giving blood at a DoveLewis Blood Bank in Portland, Ore., last month.

item.title: Russia Tightens Grip on Wagner Units in Africa, Year After Failed Mutiny
item.description: Moscow has largely taken over the African operations of the paramilitary group, once led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, who was killed after leading an insurrection against Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Russian military instructors appeared on state television in Niger after arriving in the capital, Niamey, in April.

item.title: Israel’s Supreme Court Rules Ultra-Orthodox Jews Must Be Drafted Into Military
item.description: The court ruled there was no legal justification for the ultra-Orthodox exemption from service, a decision that threatened to split Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s wartime government.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Una protesta contra el reclutamiento de los ultraortodoxos en el ejército israelí en Jerusalén en abril

item.title: An Israeli panel warns Netanyahu over corruption case, and other news.
Tuesday Briefing
item.description: An attack in Dagestan rekindled Russian fears of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: The National Antiterrorism Committee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A still from a video released by the Russian government said to show damage from the attacks in Dagestan.

item.title: 2 Russian Women Put on a Play. Then the State Came for Them.
item.description: The prosecution of a prominent playwright and a director in Russia over their work is a chilling sign of increased repression, cultural figures say.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Yevgenia Berkovich, left, and Svetlana Petriychuk inside a courthouse in Moscow in May. The two are being tried on charges of terrorism relating to the production of their play, “Finist the Brave Falcon.”

item.title: Zelensky Removes Gen. Yurii Sodol Amid Criticism of Excessive Casualties
item.description: The announcement by Ukraine’s president on Monday came hours after a scathing social media post implicitly accused the general of “killing more Ukrainian soldiers than any Russian general.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine announced that he was replacing Gen. Yurii Sodol as commander of the Joint Forces of the Armed Forces with Brig. Gen. Andrii Hnatov.

item.title: Julian Assange, WikiLeaks Founder, Agrees to Plead Guilty in Deal With U.S.
item.description: Barring last-minute snags, the deal would bring to an end a prolonged battle that began after the WikiLeaks founder became alternately celebrated and reviled for revealing state secrets in the 2010s.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: WikiLeaks, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still image from a video posted by WikiLeaks showed Julian Assange boarding a plane at London Stansted Airport on Monday.

item.title: Israeli Strike Kills Health Official, Gazans Say, as Gallant Visits U.S.
item.description: Israel’s defense minister, Yoav Gallant, was meeting with the C.I.A. director and the secretary of state on Monday as Israel signaled a potential shift in its military campaign in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Mike Ives and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Mourning the death of Hani al-Jaafarawi, Gaza’s ambulance and emergency teams chief, during his funeral on Monday, after Gazan officials said he was killed in an overnight Israeli strike on a clinic in Gaza City.

item.title: Deadly Attacks in Russia’s Dagestan Region: What to Know
item.description: Gunmen killed at least 20 people in attacks in two Dagestan cities. No suspects or motives have been identified, but the region has long been rocked by ethnic and religious violence.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A memorial on Monday in front of the Holy Assumption Cathedral after an attack on Sunday in Makhachkala, in the Dagestan region of Russia.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Dagestan Attack Revives Terrorism Fears in Russia
item.description: Also, a shift in Israel’s focus and extreme heat in Mecca.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: The National Antiterrorism Committee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A still from a video released by the Russian government yesterday of officers after the attacks in Dagestan.

item.title: Scotland Yard Had Doubts About Will Lewis’ Cooperation
item.description: Will Lewis gave a “green light” to delete emails during a major journalism scandal engulfing Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp.
item.dc:creator: Jo Becker and Justin Scheck
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Will Lewis

item.title: France’s Far-Right Leader Says the National Rally Is Ready to Govern
item.description: If he becomes prime minister after snap elections, Jordan Bardella, the party’s president, said he would represent all. But he also said dual citizens should not hold some “sensitive” jobs.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Jordan Bardella, president of the National Rally party, speaking at a news conference in Paris on Monday ahead of legislative elections.

item.title: 4 Scenarios for Next Phase in Gaza War, With ‘Intense’ Fighting Set to End
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday that the conflict is about to enter a new stage. Here are four ways that may play out, both in Gaza and at Israel’s northern border.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers near the border with Gaza in southern Israel last week.

item.title: In Greece, Another Tourist Found Dead Amid Scorching Heat Wave
item.description: At least 10 foreign tourists have gone missing or been found dead this year in Greece after going for a hike, often in scorching temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A woman fanning someone on a bench in front of the Parthenon at the ancient Acropolis in Athens this month. Because of the extreme heat, Greek authorities took the unusual steps earlier this month to temporarily restrict visiting hours to the Acropolis and several other ancient sites.

item.title: Hajj Deaths in Saudi Arabia: What to Know
item.description: The number of deaths during the annual Islamic pilgrimage raised questions about Saudi Arabia’s preparations for intense heat and unregistered participants.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A pilgrim being evacuated by medics this month at the base of Mount Arafat, one of the sites of pilgrimage in the hajj.

item.title: Iran’s Onerous Hijab Law for Women Is Now a Campaign Issue
item.description: In a sign that a women-led movement has gained ground, all of the men running for president have distanced themselves from the harsh tactics used to enforce mandatory hijab.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women in Tehran on Thursday, a week before the presidential election, none wearing the required hijab covering their hair.

item.title: Princess Anne Hospitalized With Minor Injuries After Incident
item.description: The younger sister of King Charles III sustained a concussion after an incident on Sunday, Buckingham Palace said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Princess Anne, left, attended the Royal Ascot horse races last week. Her son Peter Phillips is at right and Lady Gabriella Kingston is at the center.

item.title: Death Toll in Dagestan Church and Synagogue Attacks Rises, Officials Say
item.description: A deadly assault in the southern region of Dagestan has put a spotlight on the failing of Russian security services amid the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: The National Antiterrorism Committee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A still from a video released by the Russian National Antiterrorism Committee on Monday of officers after the attacks in Dagestan, Russia.

item.title: Death Sentence Reversed for Iranian Rapper Toomaj Salehi, Lawyer Says
item.description: Toomaj Salehi had been sentenced to death in April after releasing music in support of antigovernment demonstrations two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Demonstrators at a rally in Berlin in April condemning the death sentence for Toomaj Salehi and supporting women in Iran.

item.title: Heavy Rain and Deadly Flooding in Southern China, in Photos
item.description: The city of Meizhou reported a “once-in-a-century” flood, with at least 38 people dying in one county alone.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: The death toll from heavy rains in Meizhou, China, has jumped in recent days.

item.title: Many African Nations Want France Out. This Country Wants It In.
item.description: France is facing deep anticolonial resentment across Africa, but has found a partner in Rwanda, which is embracing French influence despite years of acrimony.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Guillem Sartorio
item.media:description: Mashauri Muhindo Memcan, the head of the French department at the Good Haven International School in Kigali, Rwanda, in April. The French language, once snubbed, is back in classrooms in the Central African nation.
